text: You entered the world with a cry. The hospital lights were bright, and strangers in masks smiled down at you.
You were born early. Weeks in the NICU, wires and beeping machines. Your parents watched through the glass.
You took your first wobbly steps. Everyone clapped. You promptly fell on your diaper.
You said your first word. Your parents argue over whether it was 'mama' or 'dada'.
First day at daycare. You cried when mom left, then forgot about her within ten minutes.
Fresh produce is expensive in your neighborhood; meals are mostly processed food.
You threw yourself on the supermarket floor screaming for candy. Your mom pretended she didn't know you.
Your parents read you a fantastical story before bed.
The apartment walls are thin. The noise next door makes it hard to sleep.
You made your first real friend at the playground. You shared your juice box.
You fell off the swing and scraped your knee. The band-aid had cartoon characters on it.
Another kid grabbed your toy. You learned that sharing is mandatory, not optional.
You wore a tiny cap and gown. Mom took 200 photos. You just wanted the cake.
The letters started making sense. You read your first word out loud and felt like a genius.
Dad let go of the seat. You wobbled, panicked, then realized you were doing it alone.
A new school year begins. New routines, new expectations. Friendships shift as you grow.
Your time comes peacefully. The story ends here.
A sudden heart attack strikes without warning.
First day of school! You got a new backpack.
You get accepted into a key high school. The workload is intense, but so are the opportunities.
You enroll in a normal high school. Steady pace, steady progress.
You go to a vocational track (Zhongzhuan). You start learning practical skills early.
You got into Beijing Normal University Experimental High School (北师大附属实验中学). The international department is a pipeline to American universities.
You got into Dalian American International School. You feel like your future ends here.
You got into Tsinghua International School. The people are talented, but the teachers and staffs are Martian
You attend an international school. Classes in English, diverse classmates, and tuition that could buy a car.
You head to Duke. The tuition is brutal, but the network is real.
Harvard, Yale, Princeton... the name opens doors before you even walk through them.
UC Berkeley. World-class academics and California sunshine. Your parents brag at every family dinner.
You attend a small liberal arts college in New England. Nobody in China has heard of it, but the education is solid.
You get into Tsinghua (清华). The campus is elite, and so are your classmates. Welcome to China's MIT.
You're going to Peking University (北大). The birthplace of Chinese intellectualism. Your parents cry happy tears.
Fudan University (复旦) in Shanghai. Top academics with big-city energy. Your future looks bright.
Shanghai Jiao Tong University (上海交大). Engineering powerhouse. You'll be building China's future.
Zhejiang University (浙大) in Hangzhou. Beautiful campus, strong programs, and Alibaba is just down the road.
Renmin University (人大). The school for future officials and economists. Your network will be powerful.
Nanjing University (南大). One of China's oldest and most prestigious. The campus drips with history.
Wuhan University (武大). Cherry blossoms in spring, rigorous academics year-round. Central China's pride.
Xi'an Jiaotong University (西安交大). A 985 school with deep roots. The ancient capital welcomes you.
Sichuan University (川大) in Chengdu. Good school, great food, pandas nearby. Life-work balance achieved.
Huazhong University of Science and Technology (华科). The 'MIT of the South'. Prepare for intense competition.
You got into a 211 university. Not the top tier, but still a respected institution. Your parents are relieved.
You attend your provincial university. Close to home, affordable tuition. A practical choice.
A private university (民办大学). The tuition is steep, but at least you got a bachelor's degree track.
You enter a junior college (大专). Three years, practical skills, straight to the workforce.
Vocational school (职业技术学院). Learn a trade, get certified, start earning. Not everyone needs a degree.
University isn't in the cards. You enter the workforce directly. The real education begins now.
Freshman orientation. You wore the lanyard, attended the icebreakers, and pretended to remember everyone's names.
Your roommate snores like a chainsaw and leaves dishes in the sink. You learn the art of passive-aggressive notes.
The dining hall mystery meat strikes again. You've memorized which days to avoid.
Your first all-nighter. Three energy drinks, two mental breakdowns, one paper submitted at 7:59 AM.
Time to declare a major. You picked something that sounded interesting. Your parents asked about job prospects.
You changed your major. Again. The advisor sighed but signed the paperwork.
You joined a club. Free pizza at meetings, actual friends as a bonus.
You finally went to office hours. The professor was surprisingly human.
You bombed an exam. The curve didn't save you. Life went on anyway.
Your first real college party. The music was too loud, but you felt like you belonged.
You have a favorite spot in the library. The chair is uncomfortable, but it's yours.
You've eaten instant noodles for the fifth day in a row. Your body is 60% MSG now.
You formed a study group. Half the time was actual studying. The other half was complaining about the professor.
Your college relationship ended. You listened to sad music and overshared with your roommate.
Finals week. The library is packed at 3 AM. Everyone looks haunted. You are one of them.
Back home for summer. Your bed feels smaller, your room feels foreign, but mom's cooking hits different.
Internship application season. You rewrote your resume twelve times and still feel underqualified.
Your first internship. You made coffee, attended meetings you didn't understand, and called it 'experience'.
Senior thesis. You became an expert on something nobody else cares about. Worth it anyway.
Graduation is approaching. Everyone asks about your plans. You smile and change the subject.
You tossed your cap in the air. Four years compressed into a single ceremony. Now what?
The first student loan statement arrived. The number had more digits than expected.
You showed up to a 9 AM lecture still hungover. You understood nothing but survived.
You made a friend who actually gets you. Late night conversations about everything and nothing.
You turned all your white clothes pink. Mom was right about separating colors.
The class is going to the Science Museum, but the fee is hard for your family to cover.
You got your first library card. The world just got bigger.
Your first tooth fell out during lunch. The Tooth Fairy left money under your pillow.
You got a pet goldfish. You promised to feed it every day. You forgot within a week.
Swimming lessons at the community pool. You learned to float on your back.
You memorized the multiplication tables. 7x8 still trips you up sometimes.
You had one line in the school play. You practiced it 500 times and still stumbled on stage.
Your first sleepover at a friend's house. You stayed up past midnight and felt invincible.
You built a volcano for the science fair. It erupted perfectly and got vinegar on the judge's shirt.
You started getting a weekly allowance. You spent it all on candy immediately.
You made it to the third round of the spelling bee before misspelling 'necessary'.
You broke your arm doing something dumb. Everyone signed your cast.
You got your first phone. It was a hand-me-down, but you felt like you'd joined the modern world.
Summer camp! Mosquito bites, campfire songs, and friendships that lasted exactly two weeks.
You try to hide your free-lunch ticket so the other kids won't tease you.
Your home internet is down again. You sit outside a cafe to upload your homework.
You grew three inches over the summer and your voice cracked.
Your crush liked someone else. You listened to sad songs on repeat for a week.
The acne arrived without warning. You tried every cream in the pharmacy.
Group project. You did all the work. Everyone got the same grade.
Your friends are at expensive tutoring camps. You study alone in your room.
You spent all day overthinking a text message you sent to your crush.
The guidance counselor suggests a trade school, despite your high grades.

branches.text: You apply to university anyway, fueled by spite.

text: High school is over. The future is wide open.
You passed your driving test on the second try. Freedom on four wheels.
First part-time job. You learned that minimum wage feels even more minimum after taxes.
Prom night. Awkward photos, rented clothes, and memories that seemed bigger than they were.
A prestigious firm offers an internship, but it pays $0. You can't afford to take it.
You deliver food on your bike between classes to make rent.
You sent 50 resumes. A friend suggests changing your name to sound more 'traditional'.
You got into a coding bootcamp designed for underrepresented groups.
You bonded with colleagues over cheap drinks.
A trendy coffee shop opened downstairs. Your landlord immediately raised the rent.
Five weddings in one year. Your savings are obliterated.
You were passed over for promotion in favor of the boss's golf buddy.
You have a weird pain, but your insurance deductible is too high to see a specialist.
Your weekend project finally started making real money.
You are caring for aging parents and young children at the same time.
You organized a neighborhood watch and cleaned up the local park.
During an interview, they asked if you could 'keep up with the fast pace'.
The local bank branch closed. You struggle with the confusing mobile app.
You grew the perfect tomato. Life is good.
You signed your first lease. The place is tiny, but it's yours.
Everyone at work seems to know what they're doing. You're pretty sure you're faking it.
You lie awake wondering if this is really what you want to do with your life.
You finally took a real vacation. The out-of-office reply felt like freedom.
Your best friend moved to another city for a job. You promised to visit but life got busy.
You signed up for a gym. You went three times in January, then never again.
You adopted a cat. It ignores you completely, but you've never felt less alone.
You finally got promoted. The raise was smaller than expected, but the title felt good.
Your back hurts now. You're not sure when that started.
High school reunion. Everyone looked older but acted the same.
Your first child was born. Sleep became a distant memory.
You got approved for a mortgage. You're now in debt for 30 years, but at least it's yours.
Your kid took their first steps. You forgot every sleepless night instantly.
Daycare costs more than rent. You briefly consider quitting your job.
You've been doing the same job for years. The ceiling feels lower than it used to.
Your parent got sick. Suddenly they seem much older than you remembered.
Your kid started school. You cried more than they did.
You needed reading glasses. The eye doctor said it happens to everyone.
You picked up a new hobby. Everyone said it was a midlife crisis, but you don't care.
Your kid became a teenager. Suddenly you know nothing and everything is embarrassing.
Your knee started making a clicking sound. You pretend not to notice.
Your kid is applying to colleges. The house will be quiet soon.
The doctor found something in your routine checkup. More tests needed. You didn't sleep for a week.
The test results came back fine. You promised yourself you'd eat better. You meant it this time.
Your kid graduated. You took too many photos and cried in public.
The house is quiet now. You're not sure what to do with all this space.
With the kids gone, you and your partner actually talked. Like really talked.
Your parent passed away. You're now the oldest generation.
You started calculating if you could retire early. The spreadsheet said no.
A young colleague asked for your advice. You felt ancient, but also useful.
Your first grandchild was born. All the best parts of parenting, none of the midnight feedings.
They threw you a retirement party. The cake was bad, but the speeches made you cry.
Retirement is boring. You've watched everything on TV and reorganized the garage twice.
You started volunteering. Turns out having a purpose matters more than having a salary.
You got the senior discount without asking. Mixed feelings.
The grandkids visited. You spoiled them rotten and sent them home hyper.
You reconnected with an old friend. Fifty years vanished in five minutes.
You got a hip replacement. The recovery was hard, but you can walk without pain again.
You sold the house and moved somewhere smaller. Too many memories to pack.
Fifty years married. You've forgotten more arguments than most people have.
Your grandkid had to show you how to use your phone. Again.
You wake up at 5am every day now. Not by choice, just how it is.
You spent the afternoon looking at old photo albums. Everyone looked so young.
Your first great-grandchild was born. Four generations now.
Your daily walk is shorter than it used to be. But you still go.
Another friend passed. You're running out of people who remember the old days.
You sat on the porch with a cup of tea and watched the sunrise. That was enough.
The 100,000 RMB consultant says your profile is too boring. They force you to fly to a remote village to 'teach English' for a week just to take photos for your resume.
You discover that your expensive counselor just used a ChatGPT to write your 'Personal Statement.' When you confront them, they block you on WeChat. The money is gone.
Because your family lacks the local 'Hukou' (residency permit), you cannot attend the well-funded public school nearby.
Your parents work in a factory in Guangdong. You only see them during Lunar New Year. Grandma raises you.
The international kindergarten requires an interview. Your mom coached you for weeks to say 'Apple' correctly.
You put on the Red Scarf for the first time. The teacher says it is dyed with the blood of martyrs.
The loudspeaker blares 'Protected Eyesight, Eye Exercises begin.' You press your thumbs against your temples mechanically.
The teacher moved you to the back row, near the trash can, because your grades dropped.
Your mom gave the Homeroom Teacher a 'gift card' for Mid-Autumn Festival. Suddenly, you are appointed Class Monitor.
While other kids play, you spend weekends at 'Aoshu' (Math Olympiad) cram schools to boost your middle school chances.
The school cafeteria food tastes sour. News breaks that the contractor was using expired meat to save money.
Your giant blue sack-like uniform is secondhand and faded. The city kids have tailored ones.
The school posts everyone's exam scores on a giant red sheet in the hallway. You search for your name.
The Dean catches you holding hands with a classmate. You are forced to write a 'Self-Criticism' letter and read it to the school.
The High School Entrance Exam (Zhongkao). 50% of your classmates will be sent to vocational schools.
You didn't make the cutoff for high school. You are sent to a vocational school to learn welding. The teachers don't really care.
You got into a 'Key High School' (Zhongdian). The pressure is suffocating, but the university acceptance rate is 90%.
Your English teacher mocks your rural accent. The classmates who spent summers in America snicker.
Your school operates like a military camp. 6:00 AM wake up, 11:00 PM sleep. No hobbies, only test papers.
Your grades are mediocre, but your dad sells an apartment to send you to a university in Australia.
The National College Entrance Exam. Police block the roads. Millions of students fight to cross the 'single-plank bridge'.
You got a high score, but because you are from a populous province with few universities, the cutoff is higher for you.
University dorm. 8 people in one room, no AC. Your roommates are from all over China.
Your parents beg you to take the Civil Service Exam (Guokao) for the 'Iron Rice Bowl'. Stability is everything.
You landed a job at a big tech firm. 9am to 9pm, 6 days a week. The pay is good, but you haven't seen the sun in weeks.
The competition is endless ('Neijuan'). You consider 'lying flat' (Tang Ping) and quitting your job to go back to your hometown.
Your parents put your resume on an umbrella at the People's Park matchmaking corner. They emphasize your height and salary.
You need to buy an apartment to get married. The down payment requires the 'Six Wallets' of your parents and grandparents.
Your parents packed huge bags and left for the city. You chased the bus crying until you fell. Grandma picked you up.
Harvest season. You skipped school to help shuck corn until your fingers bled.
Grandpa is sick. The family needs money. You decide to quit school and follow your cousin to a factory in Dongguan.
The stamping machine malfunctioned. You lost a finger. The boss gave you 500 RMB and told you to stop crying.
You collapsed on the construction site. The ambulance came, but the hospital requires a massive deposit because you have no local insurance.
Years of inhaling factory dust caught up with you. You passed away quietly in your rental room, dreaming of the village stream.
While other kids play in mud, you are forced to sit on a bench for 4 hours practicing scales. 'It's for your future,' Mom says.
Summer vacation! Your class went on a 'Study Tour' to the UK. You took a selfie with Big Ben.
You didn't like your first job, so you quit to 'find yourself' in Tibet. Your parents paid the bills.
Wedding gift! Your parents transferred the title of an old apartment to your name.
Your parents enrolled you in a bilingual kindergarten. You learned to say 'apple' before '苹果'.
Summer camp in America! You improved your English, made friends from around the world, and discovered peanut butter.
SAT prep classes every weekend. Your vocabulary now includes words like 'ubiquitous' and 'paradigm' that you'll never use again.
TOEFL practice tests every day. You dream in listening comprehension passages about campus bookstores.
Your college counselor helped you craft the perfect 'personal narrative'. You wrote about your grandmother's dumplings as a metaphor for cultural identity.
November came. You submitted your early decision application and refreshed your email obsessively for weeks.
The email arrived. 'Congratulations!' Your mom cried. Your dad immediately posted on WeChat Moments.
Rejection after rejection. 'We regret to inform you...' became the most hated phrase in English.
F-1 visa interview at the US Embassy. You dressed formally, prepared every possible question, and got approved in 2 minutes.
Your parents took you to the airport. Mom packed too many instant noodles in your luggage. You didn't look back at security.
Everything is different. The food, the humor, the social norms. You miss home but don't want to admit it.
Thanksgiving break. The dorms emptied out. You ate instant noodles and video-called your parents at 3 AM.
H-1B lottery season. Your future in America depends on a random number generator. The anxiety is real.
You moved back to China. 'Haigui' (sea turtle returnee) sounds prestigious, but readjusting is harder than expected.
You attend the 'Affiliated Kindergarten of the Bureau'. The food is organic, and the teachers are afraid of your dad.
You didn't even submit a resume. Your uncle made a call, and now you have a stamped internship certificate.
Your job consists of reading the newspaper and drinking tea. The 'Iron Rice Bowl' is boring but unbreakable.
The unit offered 'Internal Purchase Housing' at 30% of the market price.
Your private migrant school was deemed 'non-compliant' and demolished. You have nowhere to go for a month.
You tried to speak the local dialect to fit in, but the shopkeeper rolled her eyes at your accent.
The city is 'cleaning up the low-end population'. Your landlord kicked you out with 2 days notice.
Grandma stuffs you with pork belly every meal. You are the 'Little Emperor', and you are getting chubby.
Your father had a stroke. You are the only one who can sign the papers, pay the bills, and stay up all night.
You have never owned new clothes. Everything you wear belonged to your older cousin first.
You got into college! But your parents say they can only afford tuition for your younger brother.
You spent 12 hours arguing on Tieba that salty tofu is better than sweet. Your account got banned for 'provoking trouble'.
You insulted someone online. Turns out they know where you work. You got a warning from HR.
You cut a hole in your textbook to hide a comic book. The teacher is impressed by how focused you look.
You spent 4 hours in the office toilet watching Douyin. Your legs are numb, but you got paid for pooping.
You called the cafeteria lady 'Big Sister' and praised her hair. She gave you a double scoop of meat.
You crashed a stranger's wedding to get free food. By the end, you were leading the conga line.
Teacher called you to the board. You forgot your own name. You want the floor to swallow you.
The barber gave you a terrible haircut. You said 'It looks great, thanks' and tipped him, then cried at home.
You ordered 'Full Sugar' by accident. Your heart rate is 140 bpm sitting still.
You hit the hard pity cap again. You ate instant noodles for a month to cover the cost.
You posted a screenshot of your 10-pull with 3 SSRs. Your roommate blocked you.
Someone said 'Have a nice day'. You replied, 'What defines nice? And why only one day?' They walked away.
During a meeting, the projector light reflected off your head and blinded the intern. Dominance asserted.
You went out to buy soy sauce. You returned 3 hours later after accidentally taking a bus to the next district.
Girlfriend: 'Today is a special day.' You: 'Yes, it's the release date of the new GPU.' She left.
4:00 AM. One more turn. Just one more turn. The birds are chirping.
After a 72-hour coding marathon for the project deadline, you felt a sharp pain in your chest. Everything faded to black.
Breaking News: The US has annexed Canada to secure the strategic maple syrup reserve. They apologized immediately.
Headlines scream: 'Reunification Complete!' It turns out the servers for the Asian region of 'League of Legends' were just merged. Netizens are furious about the lag.
Germany accidentally started WWIII over a dispute regarding beer purity laws. It was resolved by lunchtime.
Aliens finally landed in Shanghai! They took one look at the housing prices, shook their heads, and flew back to Mars.
Artificial General Intelligence has achieved sentience. It decided to use 100% of global computing power to generate high-definition cat memes.
The National Football Team actually won the World Cup!! ...Oh wait, sorry, the news anchor was just reading his fanfiction on air.
Japan announced that their Prime Minister has been replaced by a life-sized Gundam. Approval ratings have hit 100%.
Australia has lost the Third Emu War. The Emu Empire now controls the entire Outback.
Bitcoin is now the official currency of Antarctica. The penguins are confused but bullish.
Elon Musk bought Mars. He renamed the planet 'X-Æ-12'. The subscription fee for oxygen is $8 a month.
Valve announced Half-Life 3. The release date is set for the year 3025.
The British Monarchy is now decided by a televised game of Rock-Paper-Scissors. The Corgis are winning.
Scientists discovered that Sichuan people have evolved a new organ specifically for processing chili oil.
A new study suggests the Earth is actually a giant donut. Flat Earthers are furious.
Global Warming was solved today! We simply turned on all the air conditioners in the world at the exact same time.
The sky turned purple for 3 seconds. The Universe's developers posted a tweet promising to patch the texture glitch soon.
The UN has unanimously declared putting pineapple on pizza a crime against humanity.
Russia announced it has successfully conquered the Moon. The Moon refused to comment on the occupation.
A time traveler appeared in front of you, slapped a sandwich out of your hand, and vanished.
South Korea has launched a Kimchi-powered rocket into space. It smells delicious.
A day at the lake turned tragic. Your weak body couldn't fight the current. The water took you under.
You fell from the monkey bars. Too frail to catch yourself, you hit the ground hard. The injury was fatal.
During PE class, your body gave out. Years of poor health caught up with you. You collapsed and never got up.
Your bike hit a pothole. Too weak to control the fall, you tumbled into traffic. It was over in an instant.
The darkness inside grew too heavy. No one noticed the signs. One night, you decided not to wake up tomorrow.
The bullying never stopped. Your spirit, already broken, finally shattered completely. You saw no way forward.
The pressure to succeed crushed what little joy remained. After failing the exam, you felt there was nothing left to live for.
You had no one to talk to. The loneliness consumed everything. In the end, the silence was all that remained.
Everyone wants to sit next to you at lunch. You're the kid who gets invited to every birthday party.
You ran for class president and won by a landslide. Your speech had everyone cheering.
You're the one who brings different friend groups together. People just naturally gravitate toward you.
At a conference, you charmed your way into conversations with industry leaders. Doors are opening everywhere.
A video of you casually being yourself went viral. People love your energy. Brand deals are flooding in.
Your team at work would follow you anywhere. Under your leadership, morale is sky-high and results follow.
Every day feels like an adventure. You find magic in puddles, bugs, and clouds shaped like dragons.
When others see problems, you see opportunities. Your positive outlook helps you bounce back from setbacks faster.
Your genuine happiness is contagious. Friends say hanging out with you always lifts their spirits.
You wake up grateful every morning. This mindset attracts opportunities and good people into your life.
You've learned that happiness comes from within. Friends envy your peaceful contentment with life.
Your grandchildren fight over who gets to sit next to you. Your warmth and joy make you everyone's favorite.
While other kids went to regular camp, you spent summer at an exclusive program with world-class instructors.
Your family hired the best tutors money could buy. Your grades soared without the struggle others faced.
Before college, you took a gap year traveling the world. The experiences shaped you in ways textbooks never could.
Your family's financial advisor set you up with a diversified investment portfolio. Money makes money.
Your business idea got funded instantly. Having existing wealth made investors trust you more.
A health scare was caught early thanks to your premium healthcare plan. Money bought you more years.
Your charitable foundation is making real impact. The recognition and connections that follow are priceless.
You retired early to a beautiful home. No financial worries, just time to enjoy life's pleasures.
Rich, charming, and genuinely happy - you're living the dream. Opportunities seem to fall into your lap.
Your wealth opens doors, your charm keeps them open, and your positive energy makes everyone want to help you succeed.
Your authentic joy and natural charisma made you an influencer sensation. Brands are paying you millions.
Your genuine care for others and magnetic personality made you a sought-after mentor. Your legacy grows.
You begin your PhD. Late nights in the lab, endless papers to read. The pursuit of knowledge consumes you.
You defended your dissertation. Dr. is now your title. Years of sacrifice finally validated.
Postdoc life. Low pay, high expectations. But your research is gaining attention in academic circles.
You landed a tenure-track position! The publish-or-perish pressure is real, but so is the prestige.
Your paper causes a stir. Colleagues around the world are citing your work. You might be onto something big.
Rumors swirl that you're on the Nobel shortlist. The phone call from Stockholm could come any October.
The call came at 5 AM. You've won the Nobel Prize. Your life's work recognized by the world.
You enrolled in drama school. Voice training, movement classes, endless auditions. The stage calls to you.
Your first real role! A small part in a TV drama. You have three lines, but you nail every one.
A supporting role in a major production. Critics notice you. 'A star in the making,' one writes.
You're the lead! Your face is on billboards. Fans recognize you on the street. This is what you dreamed of.
You're nominated for Best Actor/Actress. The red carpet awaits. Win or lose, you've made it.
And the award goes to... YOU! Tears stream down your face as you thank everyone who believed in you.
You receive a Lifetime Achievement Award. A montage of your greatest roles plays. The audience gives a standing ovation.
A coach spots your athletic potential. You're invited to join an elite youth training program.
You made the national youth team! Grueling training camps, but you're competing for your country now.
You've gone pro. Sponsors are interested. Your body is your career now - every injury is a threat.
You qualified for the Olympics! Years of sacrifice led to this. The world's biggest stage awaits.
Olympic bronze! You stand on the podium, national anthem playing. Not gold, but still among the world's best.
GOLD! You're an Olympic champion. Your nation celebrates. Children will grow up wanting to be you.
You broke the world record! Your name is etched in history. No one has ever done what you just did.
You announce retirement. Tributes pour in from around the world. Your jersey will be retired. Legend.
You start your first business. A small operation, bootstrapped with savings. The entrepreneurial journey begins.
Your business turned its first real profit! The sleepless nights are paying off. Time to think bigger.
You're expanding. New hires, new offices, new markets. The company is growing faster than you imagined.
You closed your Series A funding! Venture capitalists believe in your vision. Now the pressure really begins.
Your company is valued at over $1 billion. You're a unicorn founder. Magazine covers want your face.
IPO day. You ring the bell at the stock exchange. Your paper wealth is now very, very real.
Forbes lists you as a billionaire. From humble beginnings to the ultra-elite. The money is almost abstract now.
You establish a foundation to give back. Billions pledged to causes you believe in. Your legacy extends beyond wealth.
Her family demands 彩礼 of 380,000 yuan, a car, and an apartment. Your parents sell their only home. Love shouldn't cost this much.
You can't afford the bride price. She marries someone else. Your mother cries, blaming herself for not providing more.
The bride price is pocket change to your family. Her parents are thrilled. Money smooths everything.
You posted something 'sensitive' online. Two officers invite you for tea (喝茶). A friendly warning this time. Delete everything.
Your Weibo post went viral for the wrong reasons. 15 days administrative detention for 'picking quarrels and provoking trouble' (寻衅滋事).
Your lawyer friend disappeared. Three months later, he appears on TV making a confession. You delete his number.
You angered the wrong people online. Within hours, your ID, address, workplace, and family photos are everywhere. 开盒了.
The online mob called your employer. You're fired to 'protect company reputation'. Your crime? A controversial opinion.
A screenshot taken out of context. Thousands calling you a traitor, demanding you die. You stop checking your phone.
996 is the 'blessing' of working at a big tech company. 9am to 9pm, 6 days a week. Your body is breaking down.
Your coworker collapsed at his desk. Heart attack at 30. The company sent flowers and hired his replacement within a week.
You embrace 躺平 (lying flat). Minimum effort, minimum consumption, maximum peace. Let others chase the impossible dream.
You're 35. Job listings all say 'under 35 preferred'. Your experience means nothing. Too old for tech, too young to retire.
Company restructuring. Everyone over 35 gets 'optimized'. N+1 compensation if you sign quietly. You sign.
Former programmer, now food delivery rider. The algorithm controls your life. You race through traffic for ¥5 per order.
You bought a tiny apartment in a third-tier city. 30-year mortgage. You're a 房奴 now - slave to the house payment.
The developer went bankrupt. Your apartment is an unfinished concrete shell. You still owe the bank 2 million yuan.
You joined other homeowners to protest the unfinished building. Police dispersed you. 'Maintain stability,' they said.
Your parent needs surgery. The hospital wants ¥200,000 upfront. You sell everything. In China, one illness can destroy a family.
Your father needs a specialist. The waiting list is 6 months. But you know someone who knows someone. Money changes hands.
'Are you married? Planning children?' The interviewer asks. You know the right answer is a lie. You lie.
You announced your pregnancy. Suddenly your performance reviews tanked. The message is clear: resign quietly.
Relatives call you 剩女 (leftover woman). You have a master's degree and a good career. But unmarried at 30? Failure.
To get the permit approved, you need to stuff red envelopes (红包). Everyone does it. You do it too.
The anti-corruption campaign catches your business partner. He names names to reduce his sentence. Yours is on the list.
Your child can't attend local public school - wrong hukou. Private school costs ¥80,000/year. Or send them back to grandparents.
Your child must return to your hometown for gaokao. Different textbooks, no friends, fierce competition. The system is rigged.
Your social credit score dropped. Can't buy high-speed rail tickets. Can't fly. Your name scrolls on public screens: untrustworthy.
Your parents sacrificed everything for you. Now they're old and you can barely afford to visit. The guilt is crushing.
The pension fund might run out by 2035, they say. You've paid in for 30 years. Will there be anything left for you?
Your 6-year-old has math tutoring, English tutoring, piano, swimming, and coding classes. This is 内卷 (involution). Everyone competes, nobody wins.
The government wants you to have three children. You can barely afford one. The workplace wants zero. You have zero.
Locked in your apartment for 3 months. No income, dwindling savings, endless PCR tests. You bang pots on the balcony at midnight.
Your small business didn't survive the lockdowns. Ten years of work, gone. The rent is still due.
Your classmate posts photos from his third vacation this year. His parents bought him an apartment. You eat instant noodles.
You worked harder than anyone. But the promotion went to the boss's nephew. Meritocracy is a fairy tale for the poor.
You return home for Spring Festival. The questions begin: How much do you make? Bought a house? Married? You dread going back.
You overhear your parents arguing about money while playing knockoff games on your hand-me-down iPad. You pretend not to hear.
The shares you bought in 'Automatic Drying Diapers Inc.' 5 years ago have risen by 500%. Sometimes dumb luck beats strategy.
